This award strives to support the science and practice of food, feed, and fiber production (including forestry, wildlife, fisheries, aquaculture and floriculture) and its relationships to natural resources, processing, marketing, distribution, utilization (including nutrition), and trade. In addition, this award On September 14-18, 2015, APHIS in cooperation with the US Embassy in Ghana and Accra Veterinary Laboratory conducted a workshop aimed at strengthening the capability for laboratory technicians to master key practices for sampling and diagnosis of highly pathogenic avian influenza, newcastle disease, and other poultry diseases. 22 participants from Ghana (18), Nigeria (1), Cote d’Ivoire (1) The Gambia (1) and Niger (1) attended the training held at Accra Veterinary Laboratory (AVL). A primary portion of the training included: conducting and interpreting diagnostic tests (Serology and Rapid tests) and an introduction to PCR in AI/ND/IBD diagnosis (RNA extraction). This course has led to the initiative to develop training on biosafety and biosecurity in the Laboratory which was conducted the final session of the course.

description.narrative: The U.S. government provides significant assistance to accelerate Ghana's transition towards an established lower middle-income country status. U.S. assistance supports Ghana's efforts to solidify its position as a leader in a region unfortunately known for civil strife, poor governance and economic stagnation. U.S. assistance to Ghana is supported through a number of presidential initiatives and foreign assistance priorities, including Feed the Future (FTF), the Global Health Initiative, and Power Africa, as well as through support from the regional Trade Africa program. To support Ghana to achieve its development goals, U.S. assistance will promote good governance; improve health care; strengthen the basic education system; expand agricultural production; increase access to power; and enhance the capacity of the Ghanaian armed forces.
